# Cambridge International AS & A Level

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[735, 211, 905, 256]]<|/det|>  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 276, 324, 293]]<|/det|>
## FURTHER MATHEMATICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[832, 277, 905, 292]]<|/det|>
9231/22  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 300, 368, 316]]<|/det|>
Paper 2 Further Pure Mathematics 2  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[707, 301, 905, 316]]<|/det|>
October/November 2022  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[841, 325, 905, 340]]<|/det|>
2 hours  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 355, 393, 370]]<|/det|>
You must answer on the question paper.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 384, 393, 400]]<|/det|>
You will need: List of formulae (MF19)  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 418, 228, 434]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 435, 280, 450]]<|/det|>
Answer all questions.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 450, 760, 466]]<|/det|>
Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 466, 806, 482]]<|/det|>
Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 482, 562, 497]]<|/det|>
Write your answer to each question in the space provided.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 498, 485, 512]]<|/det|>
Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 513, 361, 527]]<|/det|>
Do not write on any bar codes.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 528, 866, 559]]<|/det|>
If additional space is needed, you should use the lined page at the end of this booklet; the question number or numbers must be clearly shown.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 560, 480, 575]]<|/det|>
You should use a calculator where appropriate.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 575, 880, 606]]<|/det|>
You must show all necessary working clearly; no marks will be given for unsupported answers from a calculator.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 606, 858, 637]]<|/det|>
Give non- exact numerical answers correct to 3 significant figures, or 1 decimal place for angles in degrees, unless a different level of accuracy is specified in the question.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 666, 220, 680]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 682, 384, 697]]<|/det|>
The total mark for this paper is 75.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 698, 728, 713]]<|/det|>
The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ].

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 72, 99, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 146, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 71, 628, 89]]<|/det|>
Find the set of values of \(k\) for which the system of equations

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[433, 98, 567, 116]]<|/det|>
\[x + 2y + 3z = 1,\]

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[430, 119, 567, 136]]<|/det|>
\[kx + 4y + 6z = 0,\]

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[430, 139, 567, 157]]<|/det|>
\[7x + 8y + 9z = 3,\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 165, 329, 183]]<|/det|>
has a unique solution.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 165, 920, 183]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[109, 688, 143, 707]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 688, 920, 725]]<|/det|>
Interpret the situation geometrically in the case where the system of equations does not have a unique solution.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 705, 920, 725]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 75, 97, 94]]<|/det|>
<label>3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 75, 144, 94]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 75, 920, 116]]<|/det|>
A curve has equation \(y = \mathrm{e}^{x} + \frac{1}{4}\mathrm{e}^{-x}\), for \(0\leqslant x\leqslant 1\). Find, in terms of \(\pi\) and e, the area of the surface generated when the curve is rotated through \(2\pi\) radians about the \(x\)-axis.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 96, 920, 114]]<|/det|>
<mark>[6]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 96, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 465, 89]]<|/det|>
Find the solution of the differential equation

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[395, 98, 601, 125]]<|/det|>
\[(4t^{2} - 1)\frac{\mathrm{d}x}{\mathrm{d}t} +4x = 4t^{2} - 1\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 133, 648, 152]]<|/det|>
for which \(x = 3\) when \(t = 1\). Give your answer in the form \(x = \mathrm{f}(t)\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 133, 920, 152]]<|/det|>
<mark>[9]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 72, 96, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>5</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 143, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 71, 445, 88]]<|/det|>
Write down the fourth roots of unity.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 72, 918, 88]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 163, 146, 181]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 163, 457, 181]]<|/det|>
Use de Moivre's theorem to show that

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[376, 192, 623, 211]]<|/det|>
\[\cos 4\theta = 8\cos^{4}\theta -8\cos^{2}\theta +1.\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 194, 918, 212]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 144, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 72, 490, 88]]<|/det|>
Hence obtain the real roots of the equation

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[391, 100, 606, 120]]<|/det|>
\[16(8x^{4} - 8x^{2} + 1)^{4} - 9 = 0\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 133, 551, 152]]<|/det|>
in the form \(\cos (q\pi)\), where \(q\) is a rational number.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 133, 920, 152]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 94, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>6</label>

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[175, 84, 824, 288]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 303, 920, 344]]<|/det|>
The diagram shows the curve \(y = \frac{1}{\sqrt{x^2 + 2x}}\) for \(x > 0\), together with a set of \((n - 1)\) rectangles of unit width.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 355, 633, 374]]<|/det|>
By considering the sum of the areas of these rectangles, show that

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[272, 375, 722, 415]]<|/det|>
\[\sum_{r = 1}^{n}\frac{1}{\sqrt{r^{2} + 2r}} < \ln \bigl(n + 1 + \sqrt{n^{2} + 2n}\bigr) + \frac{1}{3}\sqrt{3} - \ln \bigl(2 + \sqrt{3}\bigr). \quad (10)\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[876, 384, 920, 403]]<|/det|>
<mark>[10]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 97, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>7</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 73, 144, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 920, 108]]<|/det|>
It is given that \(\lambda\) is an eigenvalue of the non-singular square matrix \(\mathbf{A}\), with corresponding eigenvector \(\mathbf{e}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 117, 803, 138]]<|/det|>
Show that \(\lambda^{-1}\) is an eigenvalue of \(\mathbf{A}^{-1}\) for which \(\mathbf{e}\) is a corresponding eigenvector.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 119, 920, 138]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 291, 316, 310]]<|/det|>
The matrix \(\mathbf{A}\) is given by

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[428, 316, 571, 373]]<|/det|>
\[\mathbf{A} = \begin{pmatrix} 2 & 0 & 3 \\ 15 & -4 & 3 \\ 3 & 0 & 2 \end{pmatrix}.\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 382, 146, 401]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 381, 710, 401]]<|/det|>
Given that \(-1\) is an eigenvalue of \(\mathbf{A}\), find a corresponding eigenvector.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 382, 920, 401]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 574, 181, 593]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[186, 560, 917, 621]]<|/det|>
It is also given that \(\begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ 1 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix}\) and \(\begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 2 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix}\) are eigenvectors of \(\mathbf{A}\). Find the corresponding eigenvalues.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 584, 920, 603]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 75, 148, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>(d)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 73, 720, 94]]<|/det|>
Hence find a matrix \(\mathbf{P}\) and a diagonal matrix \(\mathbf{D}\) such that \(\mathbf{A}^{-1} = \mathbf{P}\mathbf{D}\mathbf{P}^{-1}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 75, 920, 92]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 339, 186, 358]]<|/det|>
<label>(e)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 338, 920, 374]]<|/det|>
Use the characteristic equation of \(\mathbf{A}\) to show that \(\mathbf{A}^{-1} = p\mathbf{A}^{2} + q\mathbf{I}\), where \(p\) and \(q\) are rational numbers to be determined.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 354, 920, 373]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 73, 96, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>8</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 479, 92]]<|/det|>
It is given that \(y = \cosh u\), where \(u > 0\), and

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[277, 106, 722, 146]]<|/det|>
\[\sqrt{\cosh^{2}u - 1}\biggl (\frac{\mathrm{d}^{2}u}{\mathrm{dx}^{2}} +\frac{\mathrm{d}u}{\mathrm{dx}}\biggr) + \cosh u\biggl (\frac{\mathrm{d}u}{\mathrm{dx}}\biggr)^{2} - 2\cosh u = 4\mathrm{e}^{-x}.\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 165, 146, 184]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 165, 240, 184]]<|/det|>
Show that

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[408, 201, 589, 235]]<|/det|>
\[\frac{\mathrm{d}^{2}y}{\mathrm{dx}^{2}} +\frac{\mathrm{dy}}{\mathrm{dx}} -2y = 4\mathrm{e}^{-x}.\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 212, 920, 231]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 549, 186, 567]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 549, 670, 570]]<|/det|>
Find \(u\) in terms of \(x\), given that, when \(x = 0\), \(u = \ln 3\) and \(\frac{\mathrm{d}u}{\mathrm{dx}} = 3\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[880, 551, 920, 570]]<|/det|>
<mark>[10]

<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[432, 73, 567, 90]]<|/det|>
# Additional page  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 102, 920, 136]]<|/det|>
If you use the following page to complete the answer to any question, the question number must be clearly shown.
